Title: CUSTOMS TARIFFVALIDATIO N
text: Darling Downs-Assis tant Minister) [3.45] - I move That this Bill be now read a second time. This Bill has been brought in in pursuance of the announcement made by the Prime Minister in his policy speech to delivered on the 22nd February last, as in which he said, " It is our intention to introduce a short Bill to legalize the collection of duties under the present Tariff." It is a very short measure, and its object is simply to validate the collection of duties under the various Tariff represolutions submitted to this House since this Parliament assembeld in 1914, authorize the continuance of the collections. It covers the Tariff the 3rd December, and 1914, as well as the amending resoluthe tions by which duties were remitted in the consequence of the drought, and subseThe various Tariff referred to in the Bill relate to the main resolutions submitted on the 3rd and December, 1914, and the amending resoinlutions of the 12tli December, 1914, the De9th June, 1915, and the 12th November, As honourable members will remember, the resolution of the 12th December, 1914, provided for the remission of the duty on wheat, and the resolution of the 9th June, 1915, which was made retrospective to the 22nd February, 1915, provided for the free admission of oats, bran, pollard, hay, chaff, and straw, tliese fodder duties being subsequently in re-imposed by the resolution of the 12th The re-imposition of the duties] had the effect of restoring the Tariff to the form in which it was originally introduced. The vital clause of the Bill is clause 3, which providesAll Duties of Customs collected (whether or after the dissolution or expiry of the present House of Representatives), pursuant tn Tariff proposals to which this Act applies, be deemed to have been lawfully imposed and collected. These resolutions have not been adopted, but on the authority of them Customs duties bave been collected, and as a result large sums of money have been paid into the Consolidated Revenue. clause now proposes to validate - them. When they are validated the Tariff will remain as it has stood for some time past, until the next Parliament shall see fit to deal with it . The object of the simply to continue in force over the elections, and until the new Parliament can deal with the Tariff, the resolutions on the strength of which duties have been collected. The Government will continue to collect duties on the authority of those resolutions.

text: It will be the authority for the collection of the duties.

text: But will it be the Tariff, as the Leader of the Opposition claims ?

Speaker: Mr GROOM
Title: CUSTOMS TARIFFVALIDATIO N

The Court, has held that we have the power to collect duties on the strength of such resolutions, and where the duties are increased by a resolution of this House the Government is given authority to collect the increase so imposed. This B i ll simply purporte to continue the existing Tariff resolutions, so that the Customs authorities will be enabled to collect the duties until the new Parliament can deal with the Tariff in its entirety. They will continue to do just what they have been doing since the imposition of the increased rates.

There had not previously been a duty on picture films, and we were compelled to take the best in formation that we could get regarding its value from others than those actually engaged in importing it . I member rightly, our information was that picture film is worth about 6d. per foot, and, assuming that to be the average value, we made the duty 25 per cent, on British, and 33 per cent, on foreign film.
